conclusion: Two parallel rails with distance L = 0.5 m, inclined at θ = 30° to horizontal
Uniform magnetic field B = 0.2 T, directed vertically upward
Rod a: mass ma = 0.3 kg, resistance R = 0.1 Ω
Rod b: mass mb = 0.1 kg, resistance R = 0.1 Ω
Constant force F = 2 N applied to rod a upward along the rails
When rod a's Joule heat Qa = 0.12 J, its velocity va = 1.0 m/s
The rails are smooth with negligible resistance

premise: Gravitational force (mg sin θ down the rails), Applied force (only for rod a), Electromagnetic force due to the current in the circuit
conclusion: Determine the forces on each rod

premise: EMF in rod a: ε₁ = BLva, EMF in rod b: ε₂ = BLvb
conclusion: The total EMF in the circuit is: ε = ε₁ - ε₂ = BL(va - vb)
The current in the circuit is: I = ε/(2R) = BL(va - vb)/(2R)
The electromagnetic force on each rod is: Fa = B²L²(va - vb)/(2R), Fb = B²L²(va - vb)/(2R)

premise: F - ma·g·sin θ - Fa = 0, Fa = B²L²(va - vb)/(2R)

conclusion: Relate the Joule heat to the current
The power dissipated in rod a is P = I²R. The work done against electromagnetic force is P = Fa·va.
